docs.lead_paragraph: Restriction On a Deed In Bronx Q. I inherited land in Riverdale in the Bronx and I want to build a house there. However, there is a deed covenant stating that no building may be built without the prior written approval of a certain corporation. Records indicate that the corporation was dissolved in 1978. What should I do? . . . Dorian J. M. Chiang, Flushing, Queens. A. John Martin, vice president and general counsel to All New York Title, a title insurance agency based in Westchester, said the letter writer had several options.
docs.snippet: Restriction On a Deed In Bronx    Q. I inherited land in Riverdale in the Bronx and I want to build a house there. However, there is a deed covenant stating that no building may be built without the prior written approval of a certain corporation....

docs.lead_paragraph: ANN AND JOHN HARRELL had paid cancer insurance premiums for half a century, starting long before his liver cancer was diagnosed. So as Mr. Harrell was dying last year, Mrs. Harrell, a retiree in Windermere, Fla., turned to the insurance company for help with about $6,000 in bills that Medicare and a Medicare supplement did not pay. Instead of thousands, she said she got hundreds -- one check for $50, another for $250 -- from her carrier, the American General Life and Accident Insurance Company. ''They said that's all I was entitled to,'' Mrs. Harrell, 83, said. ''Truthfully, I've quarreled with them so much I don't want to hear from them.''

headline.main: When the Policy Covers Only One Disease

docs.abstract: Consumer groups widely critize cancer insurance; say consumers sometimes do no understand coverage limitations and can have difficult time collecting even when they do contract cancer; such insurance returns far fewer premium dollars to policyholders than standard health insurance; Aflac Inc, which spends heavily on lobbying to end New York ban on sale of such policies, defends insurance; graph; photo (L)/

docs.lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Katherine Kirk, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carter Kirk of New Orleans, was married there yesterday to Philip Blackburn Weymouth 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Weymouth Jr. of Montchanin, Del. The Very Rev. John Senette performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Church Cathedral. The Rev. Richard Channing Weymouth, a cousin of the bridegroom who is also an Episcopal priest, took part in the service. Mrs. Weymouth, 29, is an associate in private client sales at J. P. Morgan & Company in New York. She graduated from the University of Virginia, from which she also received an M.B.A. degree.

docs.lead_paragraph: SUBSCRIBERS to Money magazine may do a double take when they walk past newsstands later this month: the May issue on display will have a completely different cover from the one they received at home. While the use of multiple, or ''split,'' covers is not unusual in the magazine industry, it is uncommon among personal-finance magazines. It's a first for Money, which has been around for 25 years. Worth has done it three times, once in 1992 and twice in 1995. Kiplinger's, which is celebrating its 50th anniversary, has resisted the practice. Ditto for Smart Money.

headline.main: Double Covers: A Matter of Demographics

docs.abstract: Roundup of personal finance magazine articles; many focus on investments that dodge effects of rising interest rates; Money magazine's use for first time of different covers for subscription and newstand editions discussed; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The American Association of Retired Persons said yesterday that it had revised a sharply criticized plan to endorse selected health maintenance organizations, dropping a proposal to collect royalty payments for each of its members who joined an H.M.O. The royalties proposal had drawn fire from Government officials and industry experts, who suggested that it might violate Medicare anti-kickback laws. Federal laws forbid payments in cash or otherwise for referrals of Medicare beneficiaries.

headline.main: A.A.R.P. Dropping Plans for Royalties In a Health Program

docs.abstract: American Assn of Retired Persons says it has revised sharply criticized plan to endorse selected health maintenance organizations, dropping proposal to collect royalty payments for each of its members who join an HMO; royalties proposal had drawn fire from Govt officials and industry experts, who suggested that it might violate Medicare anti-kickback laws; Federal laws forbid payments in cash or otherwise for referrals of Medicare beneficiaries (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton today appealed for Congressional support on two crucial tests of his leadership: a bipartisan agreement on the Federal budget and a vote, scheduled for Thursday, to ratify a treaty banning chemical weapons. Brushing aside Democratic requests that he force the Republicans to put forward their own budget proposal, Mr. Clinton urged negotiators to conclude an agreement ''sooner rather than later.''

headline.main: PRESIDENT PRESSES FOR BUDGET DEAL AND ARMS TREATY

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton appeals for Congressional support on two crucial tests of his leadership: bipartisan agreement on Federal budget, and a vote, scheduled for Thursday, to ratify treaty banning chemical weapons, news conf; calls for 'honorable compromise' to continue deficit reduction; seeks to satisfy Democratic critics by emphasizing his commitment to budget that includes more money for education, health insurance for poor children and environment; warns that without ratifying treaty on chemical weapons, United States would 'go from leading the fight against poison gas to joining the company of pariah nations' (M)
docs.snippet: President Clinton today appealed for Congressional support on two crucial tests of his leadership: a bipartisan agreement on the Federal budget and a vote, scheduled for Thursday, to ratify a treaty banning chemical weapons.     Brushing aside...

docs.lead_paragraph: When Frank N. Newman took over Bankers Trust early last year, nobody was surprised that he acted like a sheriff in a Wild West town. He had to restore order after some of the boys got caught cheating in a high-stakes craps game called derivatives trading. And he tamed the cowboy culture fostered by his predecessor, Charles S. Sanford Jr. Then came the hard part. To prevent the Bankers Trust New York Corporation from declining into the equivalent of a ghost town, Mr. Newman had to find ways to make more money. He quickly decided that the way to go was investment banking, a business built on the Mom-and-apple-pie notion of long-lasting relationships. Yet that field was more crowded and less lucrative than Mr. Sanford's mainstays -- trading and orchestrating complicated, high-margin deals for customers. Not only that, Bankers Trust lagged far behind its big Wall Street competitors.

headline.main: Head of Bankers Trust Deftly Guides Turnaround

docs.abstract: Market Place column on corporate strategy of Bankers Trust New York Corp's chief executive Fred N Newman; says Newman has swiftly moved to put Bankers Trust's derivatives trading scandal behind it and to reorient the bank away from the trading business that got it in trouble; notes last summer, Bankers Trust bought Wolfensohn & Co, a mergers and acquisitions advisory firm, and announced last week it would buy Alex, Brown & Sons, a securities firm; Newman comments; graph; photos (L)
docs.snippet: When Frank N. Newman took over Bankers Trust early last year, nobody was surprised that he acted like a sheriff in a Wild West town. He had to restore order after some of the boys got caught cheating in a high-stakes craps game called derivatives...

docs.lead_paragraph: Lieut. Gov. Elizabeth McCaughey Ross said she had not spoken more than a few formal hellos to Gov. George E. Pataki in nearly a year until shortly after 4 P.M. yesterday, when Mr. Pataki called her. ''I said, 'It's so good to hear from you,' '' Ms. McCaughey Ross recalled last night in an interview in her Upper East Side apartment. But Mr. Pataki, she said, indicated that he did not have good news, and then, in what she described as a ''45-second formal statement,'' said he would be seeking a new running mate in 1998. The phone call ended soon after that.

headline.main: McCaughey Ross Says She'll Stay On

docs.abstract: Interview with New York State Lieut Gov Betsy McCaughey Ross; she says she had barely spoken to Gov Pataki for a year until his call to her yesterday to tell her he is dropping her from his ticket; asserts she will not resign, and that she expects to run for office on her own in 1998; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pedro A. Gonzalez now earns less in a week than he used to make in a day. But for his family and his neighbors here, that is progress. For the last three months Mr. Gonzalez, who said he used to be a high-ranking gang member and drug dealer, has been paid $8 an hour to drive forklifts and run other machines at Munoz Machine Products, an auto parts company that was started this year in Detroit's empowerment zone, an impoverished area where the Federal Government is trying to foster urban renewal.

headline.main: New Jobs Grow in Once-Shunned Areas

docs.abstract: Business development and new jobs for residents in impoverished Detroit area that is one of nation's six urban empowerment zones discussed in light of Detroit conference on empowerment zones attended by Vice Pres Al Gore, Secs Andrew M Cuomo and Dan Glickman and municipal officials from around nation; zones are getting $100 million each in Federal grants and about $250 million in Federal tax breaks over decade; Gore lauds consortium of seven Detroit banks for lending over $600 million in two years to businesses in zone; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health maintenance organizations were supposed to raise the level of efficiency in medical care, reduce costs and make the system more convenient for patients and doctors alike -- all departures from traditional insurance practices. But hospitals, doctors and patients are complaining that as H.M.O.'s take on many of the functions of traditional insurers, they are adding to costs and interfering with care by taking longer to pay their bills.

headline.main: Are Health Care Companies Profiting From the 'Float'?

docs.abstract: Hospitals, doctors and patients are complaining that as health maintenance organizations take on many of the functions of traditional insurers, they are adding to costs and interfering with care by taking longer to pay their bills; some of biggest HMO's are among slowest payers, as measured by accounts payable and daily medical costs; Oxford Health Plans, United Healthcare Corp and Humana Inc were, respectively, 94, 77 and 71 days behind in their payments at end of last year; three reported total of $3.23 billion in accounts payable to doctors and other medical providers on Dec 31; executives at such companies say payment numbers are misleading; table; photos (L)
